title: Sarong

  physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. It features large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds. The background is pink in colour
 and filled with secondary geometric motifs. The bottom of the batik sarong is decorated with a scrolling tendril and flower bloom pattern against a green background.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan folk costume flower (motif) geometric motifs birds (motifs) cultural diffusion

  subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs Culture diffusion

  subject_terms_3: Batik Peranakan costumes

  sgcool_label_text: The buketan design
 comprising large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds
 is shown on this sarong.  On the kepala (broad vertical panel) of this batik
 diagonal bands of floral motifs set against fern-like fillers.  The buketan is repeated on the badan (main design feature of the batik or ‘body’).  Curving
 fluid floral branches are juxtaposed to the geometric design
 an ancient Javanese ceplok motif in the background.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966)
 the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular
 exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality
 possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.  This piece is stamped “Oeij Kok Sing 18 April 1955”.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. It features large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds. The background is pink in colour, and filled with secondary geometric motifs. The bottom of the batik sarong is decorated with a scrolling tendril and flower bloom pattern against a green background.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: The buketan design, comprising large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds, is shown on this sarong.  On the kepala (broad vertical panel) of this batik, diagonal bands of floral motifs set against fern-like fillers.  The buketan is repeated on the badan (main design feature of the batik or ‘body’).  Curving, fluid floral branches are juxtaposed to the geometric design, an ancient Javanese ceplok motif in the background.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.  This piece is stamped “Oeij Kok Sing 18 April 1955”.
